Graphical abstract In this study, the influence of the pore size in mesoporous silica (SBA-15) and the loading of niobium oxide species (Nb2O5) have been evaluated on the esterification reaction of free fatty acids from castor oil to obtain products that can be used as bio-based lubricant feedstocks. Characterization techniques such as XRD, N2 sorption, Raman spectroscopy, NH3-TPD, XPS and TEM have been employed to characterize the synthesized catalysts, demonstrating the high dispersion of the niobia species. The catalytic results showed that the SBA-15 support with an average pore size of 8.5nm and a loading of 12wt.% of Nb2O5 was the best catalyst to obtain higher conversion values in the esterification reaction of ricinoleic acid. This fact was probably due to the pore diameter of this catalyst was the most suitable for the diffusion of reagents and products. The textural properties were more relevant than the acidic properties for Nb2O5 supported on silica catalysts. The reuse data indicated that the conversion values decrease after each cycle probably due to the formation of carbonaceous deposits in the active sites, discarding the niobium leaching which is negligible. The catalytic activity could be almost thoroughly recovered by using a thermal regeneration treatment. Keywords Niobium oxide Mesoporous silica Esterification Ricinoleic acid Biolubricant 1 Introduction In recent years, the use of renewable resources and raw materials has attracted considerable attention towards a sustainable development to counteract the drawbacks of traditional fossil fuels such as their unsteady prices or their contribution to greenhouse effect due to CO2 emissions. Currently more than 60% of lubricants utilized are considered as harmful for the environment and most of them come from mineral oils for which biodegradability is only around 20%. Thus, the development of vegetable oil-based lubricants to replace petroleum-based materials possesses great interest for the scientific community considering that vegetable oils show a high biodegradation degree, up to 99% [1,2]. As the direct use of conventional vegetable oils is limited due to some properties such as their oxidation and polymerization, the formation of branched and monounsaturated esters produces lubricants with more applications, since they display acceptable oxidative stability and melting points [1,3,4]. Therefore, the free fatty acids (FFA) from biomass are considered as sustainable and alternative candidates for bio-based lubricant production by using an esterification reaction [5,6]. The utilization of different vegetable oils (sunflower, soybean, palm, coconut, etc.) and lineal or branched alcohols also affects the physicochemical properties and applications of biolubricants [6,7]. However, the use of agricultural areas for growing of these plants competes with the production of food and animal feedstocks, being more suitable the non-edible oil crops [8–10]. Castor oil is an abundant non-edible vegetable oil whose worldwide production is of 1.14Mt cultivated on 12,600km2 and an average seed yield of 902kgha−1. Moreover, this plant has low cost, it grows on lands which are not suitable for food crops and tolerates diverse weather conditions, so it is an interesting alternative feedstock [11,12]. Castor oil is different from other vegetable oils being its most abundant fatty acid the ricinoleic acid (nearly 90%) which possesses a hydroxyl group in position 12, providing additional natural chemical functionality so the pertinent esters exhibit interesting properties, including high viscosity, improved lubricity and favorably high flash point [12–14]. The classic preparation method of synthetic esters is the esterification reaction between FFA and alcohol in presence of homogeneous acid catalyst, such as H2SO4, HCl, H3PO4 or RSO3H [15,16]. Nevertheless, the conventional mineral acids are corrosive and harmful, being more advisable the use of solid acid catalysts because they minimize environmental damages, they are more easily separated from the reaction medium and they can be reused [17–20]. Several solid acid catalysts have been tested for the esterification of ricinoleic acid by using different alcohols: polyaniline-sulfate [21], organo-sulfonic acids doped polyaniline [22,23], WO3 supported on porous clay heterostructure with Si-Zr pillars [24] and ion-exchange resins [25]. On the other hand, the synthetic esters produced from 2-ethyl hexanol are attractive for their applications in the cosmetic, pharmaceutical, food and chemical industries and also as components of oil bases and lubricants; thus, the esterification of FFA, such as oleic or palmitic acid, and 2-ethylhexanol has been reported in the literature by employing sulfonic acids or enzymes, as catalysts [15,16,26]. Niobium oxide (Nb2O5) has been demonstrated to have interesting acidic properties and to be highly insoluble in water [27–30], which is a key factor considering that H2O molecules are produced for esterification reaction. Hence, different Nb2O5 containing catalysts have been tested for esterification reactions of other fatty acids [31–34]. However, niobium oxide possesses a low specific surface area, being recommendable to employ high-surface supports to improve the dispersion and enhance the number of available active sites. Therefore, the use of mesoporous supports as MCM-41 or SBA-15, which exhibit high surface area and suitable chemical and thermal stabilities, favors the dispersion of the active phase, increasing the available sites of niobium oxide, as previously reported [35–39]. Moreover, the pore size of these materials can be modified by varying the synthesis conditions and using organic swelling agents such as trimethylbenzene [40–42], which could be of great interest due to the large size of the FFA molecules. The main objective of this study was the synthesis of niobium oxide supported on SBA-15 as acid catalysts, modulating the pore size of the support and the loading of Nb2O5 in order to optimize the esterification of ricinoleic acid with 2-ethylhexanol. The influence of the reaction time and temperature on the catalytic reaction was evaluated and the catalysts were characterized to determine their structure–activity relationships. Likewise the reusability of the catalysts was also assessed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts Different mesoporous SBA-15 silica were synthesized following a procedure based on the method previously described by Vilarrasa-García et al. [42]. Firstly, 4g of Pluronic (P-123, M=5800gmol−1, Aldrich) were dissolved in 144mL of 1.7M hydrochloric acid solution under magnetic stirring at 40°C. Right after, 8.75mL of the source of silica (tetraethyl orthosilicate, TEOS, Aldrich, 98%) were added dropwise. The final molar composition of the synthesis gel was P123/SiO2/HCl/H2O=1/55/350/11100. The resulting suspension was stirred at room temperature for 72h for the synthesis at room temperature and 24h for hydrothermal synthesis. In the latter case, the gel was transferred to a teflon lined reactor and placed in an autoclave, aging the gel at 120°C for 48h. Moreover, a third synthesis procedure was carried out using 1,3,5-trimethylbenzene (TMB, Aldrich, 95%) as swelling agent, which was added after the surfactant solution and before adding TEOS. Thus, 4.75mL of TMB were incorporated dropwise and TEOS was added 30min later, following the same procedure than hydrothermal synthesis. In all cases, the solid was recovered by filtration, washed and dried at 60°C, and then calcined in air at 550°C for 6h with a heating rate of 1°Cmin−1 in order to remove the surfactant. The supports were denoted as SBART, SBAHT and SBATMB for the room temperature, hydrothermal and hydrothermal with swelling agent synthesis, respectively. Likewise, a commercial silica sample (Merck, 40–63μm), denominated as Si, was employed to compare with the obtained mesoporous silica materials. Different amounts of niobium oxide were incorporated to the supports by using the incipient wetness impregnation with niobium oxalate (Alfa-Aesar). Thus, aqueous solutions of niobium oxalate in 0.1M oxalic acid were used to incorporate different amounts of Nb2O5 on the supports (2, 4, 8, 12 and 16wt%). The materials were dried in air at 60°C after impregnation and calcined at 400°C for 4h (heating rate of 2°Cmin−1). These catalysts were named as X-yNb, where X indicated the support (SBART, SBAHT, SBATMB and Si) and y represented the weight percentage of Nb2O5 in each catalyst. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts Powder diffraction patterns were collected on a PANalytical automated diffractometer, EMPYREAN model, using Cu-Kα 1,2 (1.5406Å) radiation and a last generation PIXcel detector. The database employed were ICSD, PDF 2-2004 and COD of High ScorePlus programme of PANalytical. The textural parameters were determined from nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms at −196°C, obtained using an automatic gas adsorption analyser from Micromeritics (ASAP 2020). Prior to N2 adsorption, the samples were outgassed at 200°C and 10−4 mbar for 10h. Surface areas were determined by using the Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) equation and a nitrogen molecule cross section of 16.2Å2. The Density Functional Theory method (DFT) was employed to determine the pore size distributions. Raman spectra were recorded on a FT-Raman spectrometer, using a Nd:YAG laser as the excitation source at 1064nm and the laser power was set to 100mW. Raman spectroscopy was performed on powder samples without any previous treatment. The morphology of the catalysts was studied by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), by using a FEI Talos F200X equipment which combined outstanding high-resolution S/TEM and TEM imaging with energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy (EDS) signal detection, and 3D chemical characterization with compositional mapping. X-ray photoelectron spectra were obtained with a PHI Versaprobe II with high flux x-ray source providing a focused monochromatic x-ray Al Kα beam of 100 micrometers that is scanned 1400 micrometers (large area) in the sample surface (100W, 15kV, 1486.6eV). High-resolution spectra were recorded at a given take-off angle of 45° by concentric hemispherical analyser operating in the constant pass energy mode at 29.35eV. Each spectral region was scanned several sweeps until a good signal to noise ratio was observed. The pressure in the analysis chamber was maintained lower than 1.5×10−6 Pa. Charge referencing was measured against adventitious carbon (C 1s at 284.8eV). A Shirley-type background was subtracted from the signals. Recorded spectra were always fitted using Gaussian–Lorentzian curves in order to determine the binding energies of the different element core levels more accurately. The temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was carried out to evaluate the total surface acidity of the catalysts. After cleaning of the catalysts (80mg) with helium and subsequent adsorption of ammonia at 100°C, the NH3-TPD was performed by raising the temperature from 100 to 550°C, under a helium flow of 40mLmin−1, with a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 and maintained at 550°C for 15min. The evolved ammonia was analyzed using a TCD detector of a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-14A). 2.3 Catalytic tests The free fatty acids obtained from castor oil (FACO) were supplied by Miracema-Nuodex (Campinas, Brazil), with the following composition: ricinoleic acid (85.37%), linoleic acid (6.61%), oleic acid (5.31%), palmitic acid (1.51%) and stearic acid (1.20%), and its mean molecular mass was 295.62gmol−1. The alcohol employed for esterification reaction was 2-ethylhexanol (99%, Merck). In a typical experiment, 15g of FACO, 16mL of 2-ethylhexanol and 1.5g of catalyst were added into the three-necked flask fitted with water cooled condenser, immersed in a glycerin bath, and controlling the temperature by the insertion of a thermocouple directly connected and stirring at 400rpm. A 2-EH:FACO molar ratio of 2:1 was used in all cases, which had been already optimized in previous studies [24,25]. The esterification reaction was monitored by collecting aliquots at different times, removing the catalyst by microfiltration and the excess of 2-EH by vacuum distillation at 90°C for 40min using a Kugelrohr distiller. The reaction products were quantified by titration with 0.1M NaOH solution in ethanol. Each sample was run in duplicate, and the average values are reported. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts Firstly, the powder X-ray diffraction patterns of the supports were determined in the 2θ range of 0.5–10° (Fig. 1 A). It can be observed that the commercial silica sample does not exhibit any type of order by this technique. In the case of SBA-15 synthesized at room temperature, SBART, a very intense peak at ca. 2θ=1.14° corresponding to d100 reflection confirms the long-range order of this mesostructured support. When the SBA-15 synthesis is hydrothermal (SBAHT), three well resolved peaks can be identified as (1 0 0), (1 1 0) and (2 0 0) reflections in a hexagonal arrangement. Also, the (1 0 0) diffraction signal is shifted to lower values of 2θ, which suggests the formation of an ordered structure with larger unit cell. However, these diffraction lines were not detected for the SBATMB support which may be due to the use of swelling agents as 1,3,5-trimethylbenzene causing the expansion of pores, which may confer a more disordered pore structure or shift the d100 diffraction lines to very low angle values, not being possible their detection by XRD [42,43]. On the other hand, the stability of SBA-15 supports was verified since the main peak at low angle is conserved after impregnation and subsequent calcination for the niobium species incorporation (Fig. 1B), even when a Nb2O5 loading of 16wt.% was employed in the catalysts. With regard to the XRD patterns in the high-angle region (Fig. 1C), the characteristic reflections of niobium oxide were not detected for any catalyst, so these particles are amorphous or small and well-dispersed on the surface of the supports. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms at −196°C of the supports were of Type IV according to the IUPAC classification, which is characteristic of mesoporous solids (Fig. 2 ). This same type of isotherms was found for the corresponding Nb2O5 supported catalysts (not shown). Likewise, the pore size distribution also demonstrated that the hydrothermal conditions and mainly the addition of TMB considerably increased the pore sizes for the support materials (Fig. 3 A). This same fact was found when niobium oxide was incorporated (Fig. 3B). Although some pores were blocked due to the presence of Nb2O5 particles, mainly the micropores as it can be observed in Table 1 , the pore size distribution of these catalysts revealed that higher pore sizes were obtained when the synthesis was hydrothermal, especially for SBATMB-12Nb. The textural properties of the support materials and their catalysts are compiled in Table 1. It is known that the commercial silica lacks porosity, so its surface area value was due to the external surface of this material and interparticle voids. When different SBA-15 supports were compared, SBART exhibited higher SBET values than hydrothermal synthesis SBAHT. This fact may be attributed to the high microporosity of SBART, as may be checked by micropore volume. Thus, the total pore volume increased when the synthesis was hydrothermal and, especially, if TMB was employed as swelling agent, consequently decreasing the micropores volume. A slight reduction of BET surface and micropore volume was detected after the incorporation of different amounts of niobium oxide, which is more pronounced for a loading of 12wt.%. Although it has been previously proposed that high amounts of oxalate precursor, for which the decomposition is exothermic, could partially destroy the long-range order mainly above 12wt% Nb2O5 over SBA-15 [36], the XRD patterns demonstrated that the mesoporous structure was conserved after impregnation and calcination. Therefore, niobium species would be well dispersed over the surface of the mesoporous framework. However, the decrease of SBET and Vmicropores could be due to Nb2O5 particles being partially blocking the micropores of these supports materials. Likewise, Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) (Fig. 4 ) was used to check that the porosity of commercial silica is due to the interparticle voids, as was previously indicated. In the case of SBA-15 support materials, ordered frameworks were detected in all cases, increasing the pore size when the synthesis was hydrothermal and, especially, if TMB was employed as swelling agent since it caused an increase of pore size and a decrease in the regularity of framework [44]. Moreover, the niobium species were well-dispersed on the catalytic supports as was deduced by EDX analysis of Si and Nb (Fig. 4), corroborating the XRD data. Different surface metal oxides can be identified from Raman spectroscopy, which are often responsible for catalytic activity. Hence, the Raman spectra of niobium oxide supported over different silica were realized (Fig. 5 ). Firstly, the presence of bulk Nb2O5 could be discarded due to bands at 700 and 200cm−1 were not clearly detected, which is in agreement with the results obtained by XRD [45,46]. This coincides with literature since it has been previously affirmed that higher calcination temperatures and Nb2O5 loadings are required to detect crystalline niobium oxide [46,47]. In the case of Si-12Nb and SBART-12Nb, similar bands were detected. Almost indiscernible signals were found for SBAHT-12Nb, which indicates that Nb2O5 species were well dispersed on the surface of this catalyst. However, the profile of these bands looks like similar to SBART-12Nb. For SBATMB-12Nb, the bands were narrower so different Nb environments were present in these catalysts. Thus, a broad band in the 500–750cm−1 region attributed to slightly distorted octahedral NbO6 structures was found for these catalysts, which is related to the existence of Brönsted acid sites [36,48]. Moreover, another band in the 800–1000cm−1 region was observed, mainly for SBART-12Nb. This band was associated to highly distorted octahedral NbO6 structures and related to the Lewis acid sites [48]. Finally, a band at 492cm−1 was found for SBART, which was previously assigned to tetra-cyclosiloxane rings for SBA-15 [36,49]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy is a powerful tool to get insights into the surface nature of solids. The XPS data of X-12Nb catalysts are summarized in Table 2 . The binding energy (BE) values for O 1s (532.7–532.9eV) and Si 2p (103.3–103.5eV) were characteristic of oxygen and silicon in silica respectively [35,50]. However, the Si-12Nb catalyst displayed another contribution for O 1s at 530.2eV, which was due to the presence of Nb2O5 particles in the catalyst surface [30]. On the other hand, the two components of the Nb 3d doublet were observed in such a way that the catalysts showed values of BE for Nb 3d 5/2 between 207.1–207.6eV, being typical of Nb(V) in an oxidic environment [51,52]. It should be noted that the Nb atomic concentration for the catalysts supported on SBA-15 was very low (0.54–0.63%); therefore, the niobia species were very dispersed on the support surface and/or inside of pores, as previously checked by XRD, TEM and Raman spectroscopy. This same conclusion can be obtained from the surface Nb/Si atomic ratio which exhibited lower values than the bulk one (0.062) when SBA-15 was employed as support. However, the Si-12Nb catalyst exhibited the highest Nb/Si ratio, even exceeding the bulk value, corroborating the existence of higher amount of Nb species in the surface of this material. The total acidity of catalysts was also determined by NH3-TPD (Fig. 6 and Table 1). The different silica supports did not show acidity, so the incorporation of niobium oxide enhanced the acidity of support in all cases. In the case of commercial silica and SBA-15 synthesized at room temperature, similar values of total acidity were found when 12wt% Nb2O5 was incorporated to the supports. However, this total acidity was lower when niobia was impregnated over hydrothermal SBA-15, SBAHT and SBATMB. Therefore, SBART-12Nb displayed the highest amount of available acid sites of Nb2O5 supported silica catalysts. On the other hand, an increase of total acidity was found when higher loadings of niobium oxide were incorporated to SBAHT, as expected, even up to 16wt%, corroborating the suitable dispersion of the active Nb2O5 phase. Moreover, the NH3-TPD profiles (Fig. 6) showed the existence of acid sites with a broad range of strength, since the acid strength and the ammonia desorption temperature are related and the strongest acid sites desorbed at higher temperatures [53]. Thus, it can be observed that the support influences on the acid strength of catalyst in such a way that Si-12Nb and SBART-12Nb exhibited higher amount of strong acid sites (Fig. 6A). In the case of SBAHT-yNb catalysts, the total acidity increased with the Nb2O5 loading as it has been exposed, but the acid strength of catalysts was also enhanced (Fig. 6B). However, the main band was slightly shifted at lower temperatures in the case of SBATMB-12Nb, so the acid sites of this catalyst are weaker. 3.2 Catalytic results The catalytic activity of these niobium-based catalysts was evaluated in the esterification of free fatty acids obtained from castor oil (FACO) with 2-ethylhexanol (2-EH). It was established in previous works that an optimal 2-EH:FACO molar ratio of 2:1 [24,25], so this was employed for all catalytic tests. Firstly, the influence of reaction temperature on catalytic performance for non-catalytic process (in the absence of catalyst) and in the presence of SBAHT-12Nb catalyst was determined (Fig. 7 ). It could be observed that the SBAHT-12Nb catalyst was inactive when the reaction was carried out at 100°C, since the catalytic results were almost identical to the non-catalytic process. However, the FACO conversion increased with increasing temperature and reaction time in the presence of the SBAHT-12Nb catalyst, considerably surpassing the catalytic results in absence of catalyst. This difference between non-catalytic and catalytic processes was still higher when the esterification reaction was performed at 120°C, so this temperature was chosen for the subsequent catalytic tests. A catalytic screening of niobium-based catalysts on different supports was carried out under the following experimental conditions: reaction temperature of 120°C, 10wt.% of catalyst with respect to FACO and the 2-EH:FACO molar ratio of 2:1 (Fig. 8 ). In all cases, the FACO conversions were higher than those of non-catalytic contribution, so all catalysts were active to a greater or lesser degree. When commercial silica was employed as support, the catalytic behavior of Si-12Nb hardly exceeded the results obtained in the absence of catalyst, even after 8h, obtaining 55% and 47% respectively. However, this catalyst exhibited one of the highest values of total acidity and strong acid sites which desorbed at high temperatures determined by NH3-TPD. It is probable that these results may be related to the commercial silica lacks the intrinsic porosity. Thus the Nb species were probably located on the external surface as previously deduced from the XPS data. When SBA-15 synthesized at room temperature was used as support, the catalytic results were enhanced in such a way that the FACO conversions increased up to 73% after 8h of reaction. It is certain that this material displayed the highest total acidity, but its value is very similar to Si-12Nb. Indeed, the profiles of NH3-TPD of both catalysts were almost identical. So the textural properties seem to be related to this increase of conversion. Therefore the use of a mesoporous silica favors the dispersion of Nb2O5, improving the catalytic behavior of catalysts in which the esterification reaction took place inside the pores as opposed to the commercial silica for which the reaction seems to occur on the external surface. Likewise, higher values of FACO conversion were attained by using SBAHT as support. It can be observed in Fig. 8 that the SBAHT-12Nb catalyst provided the highest conversion, reaching a value of 80% after 8h at 120°C, despite the fact that this sample had exhibited lower total acidity than Si-12Nb and SBART-12Nb. It should be noted that the average pore size of SBAHT-12Nb was higher than SBART-12Nb and the micropore volume was lower when the synthesis of SBA-15 was hydrothermal. Although the chain length of ricinoleic acid is 1.64nm [54] and the average pore size of SBART-12Nb is 3.5nm, the FFA molecule could have a conformation, which would hinder the access of these molecules to the active sites located inside the pores. On the other hand, it has been reported that both FFA and alcohol molecules are adsorbed on the catalytic surface when a bulkier alcohol such as 2-EH is employed (Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism) [55], so the FFA molecules should be able to access the interior of the pores for the esterification reaction to take place. Moreover, in spite of the fact that some molecules of ricinoleic acid were able to go into the pores of SBART-12Nb, it would be very difficult for the corresponding ester molecules, which would be bulkier, to leave these pores. Therefore, the pore size of SBART-12Nb did not present enough width to attain the maximum yield of Nb2O5 active sites. Nevertheless, the pore size distribution of SBAHT-12Nb (Fig. 3B) revealed the existence of larger pores, being the average pore size equal to 8.5nm, which would facilitate the entrance and exit of these molecules, allowing the access to Nb2O5 sites and consequently enhancing the catalytic performance. In the case of SBATMB-12Nb, the use of TMB as swelling agent led to larger pores, even after Nb2O5 incorporation (Fig. 3B and Table 1). However, it can be observed in Fig. 8 that the SBATMB-12Nb catalyst not only did not exceed the FACO conversion achieved in presence of SBAHT-12Nb, but its catalytic behavior was similar to Si-12Nb, obtaining a value of conversion equal to 58% after 8h at 120°C. In this case, an increase of pore size did not provide better catalytic results, slightly surpassing the non-catalytic contribution. This fact may be due to the pores were too large (dp =16.3nm) and the interaction of FFAs and alcohol molecules with active sites was more difficult, since the length of these compounds is considerably smaller than the pore size. Therefore, we could affirm that the pores of SBAHT support possess the optimal size to favor the interaction between the reagents and Nb2O5 sites and facilitate the esterification reaction. It should be also noted that the total acidity of SBAHT-12Nb and SBATMB-12Nb were very similar in spite of the SBAHT-12Nb was considerably more active than SBATMB-12Nb. Thus, we could affirm that the textural properties of Nb2O5-based catalysts are much more relevant than their acidic properties in the esterification of ricinoleic acid, since a suitable size of pores favors the access to these acid sites. On the other hand, if the TOF (Turnover Frequency) values expressed as μmol converted FACOμmol NH3 −1 h−1 were plotted as a function of acid sites density calculated as μmol NH3 m−2 (Fig. 9 ), a maximum can be found for SBAHT-12Nb catalyst, being again the most suitable support. However, the SBATMB-12Nb provided better catalytic performance in terms of TOF than SBART-12Nb and Si-12Nb. Hence, it could be confirmed that the textural properties were a key factor in FACO esterification with 2-EH, being even more relevant than the acidic properties. Since the SBAHT support provided the best catalytic results, the loading of niobium oxide was then studied on this material, varying it between 2 and 16wt% of Nb2O5, and these catalysts were tested in the esterification of FACO (Fig. 10 ). It can be observed that the values FACO conversion enhanced when the loading of Nb2O5 increased up to 12wt.%, reaching a value of 80% for SBAHT-12Nb after 8h at 120°C. Thus, this evolution of the catalytic performance would in agreement with the acid properties of these catalysts, since the total acidity determined by NH3-TPD increased with increasing Nb content. Therefore, the acidic properties would have certain importance when catalysts with similar pore sizes were compared. It has been previously demonstrated that the catalytic behavior of supported Nb2O5 species on mesoporous silica got worse from 16wt% Nb2O5, even for other reactions as transesterification of sunflower oil or dehydration of xylose [35,36]. However, the acidity of SBAHT-16Nb was even higher than SBAHT-12Nb, demonstrating again that the acidity was not the most relevant parameter for FACO esterification. This decrease of conversion was probably related to the effectiveness of Nb2O5 dispersion when higher amounts of niobia were incorporated to the support. However, no evidences were detected by different techniques, since crystalline Nb2O5 phases were not found by XRD. The reutilization of the solid catalysts is a key factor in the development of heterogeneous catalysis, so the activity of SBAHT-12Nb was evaluated for several catalytic runs (Fig. 11 ). Firstly, the used catalyst after one reaction cycle was recovered and characterized (u-SBAHT-12Nb). It was demonstrated that the intensity of d100 reflection decreased but it did not disappear and no crystalline phases of Nb2O5 were detected by XRD (Fig. 12 A and B). It can be detected in Table 1 that the SBET value considerably decreased from 333m2 g−1 for the fresh catalyst to 11m2 g−1 for the spent one. In addition, the pore volume decreased and the average pore size increased, which indicates that the ricinoleic acid molecules were probably blocking the smallest pores of that catalyst. The u-SBAHT-12Nb was also analyzed by XPS (Table 2). Although the BE values were maintained, it can be detected that the Nb/Si and Nb/C atomic ratios were considerably reduced. Indeed, the atomic concentration of niobium was 0.04%, which seems to indicate that carbonaceous deposits were located on the catalytic surface blocking the niobium species. This fact was also checked from the new contributions located at 286.4 and 288.8eV for C 1s, which were ascribed to the presence of carbonyl and carbonated groups [25,56], demonstrating a strong interaction between the reagents and products with the Nb sites which would be blocked for the esterification reaction. Therefore, in order to remove these physisorbed species, the catalyst was recovered after each run by filtration, then washed with hexane and finally dried at 60°C. Then, the SBAHT-12Nb catalyst was put in contact with a new reaction mixture, following the same sequence. It can be observed that the FACO conversion decreased after each catalytic run, mainly after 3 cycles, diminishing from 80% after the 1st cycle down to 52% after 5 cycles. This decrease of catalytic activity could be due to the deactivation of active sites by carbonaceous deposits or the leaching of Nb sites. However, the niobium in the reaction medium was determined by ICP-MS, being almost negligible since only 0.0012% of niobium was leached. Therefore, the catalytic deactivation would be produced by the blocking of active sites. Hence, it could be affirmed that the washing of catalyst with hexane (w-SBAHT-12Nb) was not enough to recover the activity although the Nb atomic concentration determined by XPS was 0.29%. Moreover, the Nb/C molar ratio of w-SBAHT-12Nb coincided with the value obtained for u-SBAHT-12Nb. This fact verifies that the carbonaceous deposits were located on the niobium atoms and the washing process with hexane removed some of them and released part of these Nb sites. However, the strongest niobium sites retained these deposits even after washing since the contributions of C 1s at 286.2 and 288.9eV were maintained (Table 2), consequently decreasing somewhat the catalytic performance. Finally, the regeneration of catalyst was also studied by calcination at 550°C for 4h (r-SBAHT-12Nb). This thermal treatment led to the partial recovery of SBET and total acidity values (Table 1) and the structure of fresh catalyst (Fig. 12). Likewise, the Nb atomic concentration of fresh catalyst (0.54%) determined by XPS is recovered after this treatment and the Nb/Si and Nb/C atomic ratio were very similar. However, the contribution due to carbonyl species (286.4eV) was partially maintained (Table 2), indicating that some of these species remained on the active sites which hindered the total recuperation of SBET and acidity values. With regard to catalytic behavior, the FACO conversion slightly decreased with respect to first cycle (Fig. 11) possibly due to some carbonaceous species staying on the catalytic surface as checked by XPS, since it was verified by XRD that the structure was maintained (Fig. 12). However, a high conversion value (72%) was still attained. Thus, the thermal regeneration treatment was more effective than the wash treatment with hexane to recover the activity of catalyst after esterification reaction between FACO and 2-EH. 4 Conclusions Different supported niobia catalysts on silica demonstrated to be active for bio-based lubricant synthesis from the esterification reaction of free fatty acids with 2-ethylhexanol. From characterization data, it was shown that the Nb2O5 sites were highly dispersed on all SBA-15 support materials and the loading of this active phase had direct influence on the total acidity. The use of mesoporous silica as SBA-15 as support material provided better catalytic results than when using commercial silica. In addition, the importance of pore size and textural parameters was demonstrated in such a way that it was necessary an optimal pore size to facilitate the diffusion of reagents and products and maximize FACO conversion, achieving a value of 80% for the SBA-15 support with an average pore size of 8.5nm and a loading of 12wt.% of Nb2O5. Thus, the textural properties were more relevant than the acidic properties when the same loading of niobia was studied. The acidic properties acquired certain importance when the textural parameters were very similar by using the same support. The leaching of niobium species was almost negligible, so the decrease of catalytic performance for several cycles in the reutilization study was probably due to carbonaceous deposits located on the active Nb sites, which could be removed by thermal treatment. coredata.dc:description: In this study, the influence of the pore size in mesoporous silica (SBA-15) and the loading of niobium oxide species (Nb2O5) have been evaluated on the esterification reaction of free fatty acids from castor oil to obtain products that can be used as bio-based lubricant feedstocks. Characterization techniques such as XRD, N2 sorption, Raman spectroscopy, NH3-TPD, XPS and TEM have been employed to characterize the synthesized catalysts, demonstrating the high dispersion of the niobia species. The catalytic results showed that the SBA-15 support with an average pore size of 8.5nm and a loading of 12wt.% of Nb2O5 was the best catalyst to obtain higher conversion values in the esterification reaction of ricinoleic acid. This fact was probably due to the pore diameter of this catalyst was the most suitable for the diffusion of reagents and products. The textural properties were more relevant than the acidic properties for Nb2O5 supported on silica catalysts. The reuse data indicated that the conversion values decrease after each cycle probably due to the formation of carbonaceous deposits in the active sites, discarding the niobium leaching which is negligible. The catalytic activity could be almost thoroughly recovered by using a thermal regeneration treatment.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of pore size and loading for Nb2O5/SBA-15 catalysts on synthetic ester production from free fatty acids of castor oil
